confusion_pairs.title: Vulnerability scan vs Penetration test

a.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with vulnerability scan.

b.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with penetration test.

bullets: A scan finds known weaknesses broadly; a pentest attempts to exploit weaknesses to prove impact.
If the question says 'prove/validate impact' → pentest. If it says 'identify missing patches/find CVEs at scale' → vuln scan.
Scanner flags SMBv1 on many hosts. Pentester uses SMBv1 weakness to gain access and pivot to a file server.

confusion_pairs.title: Security assessment vs Security audit

a.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with security assessment.

b.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with security audit.

bullets: Assessment = evaluate and improve; audit = verify against a standard/policy (often for compliance).
If it’s about improvement/recommendations → assessment. If it’s about evidence + compliance checking → audit.
Assessment: review controls and propose hardening. Audit: check if controls meet ISO/PCI requirements and collect evidence.

confusion_pairs.title: False positive vs False negative

a.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with false positive.

b.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with false negative.

bullets: False positive = alert says 'bad' but it's fine; false negative = alert misses something real.
‘Noise/too many alerts’ → false positives. ‘Missed attack’ → false negatives.
IDS flags normal backup traffic as exfiltration (FP). IDS fails to flag real command-and-control traffic (FN).

confusion_pairs.title: SAST (Static Application Security Testing) vs DAST (Dynamic Application Security Testing)

a.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with sast (static application security testing).

b.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with dast (dynamic application security testing).

bullets: SAST checks code without running it; DAST tests a running app from the outside.
If it mentions 'source code/compile time/CI pipeline' → SAST. If it mentions 'running web app/proxy/fuzz requests' → DAST.
SAST finds hardcoded API keys in code. DAST finds SQL injection by sending payloads to the live site.

confusion_pairs.title: Active scanning vs Passive scanning

a.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with active scanning.

b.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with passive scanning.

bullets: Active scanning sends probes to hosts; passive scanning observes existing traffic/logs without probing.
If it 'touches' systems with probes → active. If it 'listens/monitors' → passive.
Active: Nmap port scan. Passive: network sensor detects open services based on traffic patterns.

confusion_pairs.title: Credentialed scan vs Non-credentialed scan

a.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with credentialed scan.

b.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with non-credentialed scan.

bullets: Credentialed scan logs in for deeper visibility; non-credentialed scans from outside with limited visibility.
If it mentions 'agent/SSH/WinRM/AD creds' → credentialed. If it mentions 'external view' → non-credentialed.
Credentialed scan checks missing patches via OS queries. Non-credentialed scan only sees exposed ports/banners.

confusion_pairs.title: Black-box test vs White-box test

a.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with black-box test.

b.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with white-box test.

bullets: Black-box = no internal knowledge; white-box = full internal knowledge (code/diagrams/credentials).
‘No knowledge like an attacker’ → black-box. ‘Full code/architecture access’ → white-box.
Black-box: test public endpoints only. White-box: review code + configs + internal APIs.

confusion_pairs.title: Baseline vs Benchmark

a.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with baseline.

b.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with benchmark.

bullets: Baseline = your known-good normal state; benchmark = a reference standard (vendor/industry).
‘What’s normal for us?’ → baseline. ‘Best practice/hardening standard?’ → benchmark.
Baseline: normal CPU is 10–20% for this server. Benchmark: CIS hardening checklist for Windows.

confusion_pairs.title: Vulnerability vs Exploit

a.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with vulnerability.

b.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with exploit.

bullets: Vulnerability = the weakness; exploit = the method/code that uses the weakness.
If it’s ‘a flaw’ → vulnerability. If it’s ‘how attackers use it’ → exploit.
Vuln: unpatched RCE bug. Exploit: payload that triggers the bug to run attacker commands.

confusion_pairs.title: Patch management vs Vulnerability management

a.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with patch management.

b.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with vulnerability management.

bullets: Patch management is applying updates; vulnerability management is the full cycle: discover → prioritize → remediate → verify.
If it focuses on updating systems → patch mgmt. If it includes scanning, triage, risk ranking, verification → vuln mgmt.
Vuln mgmt finds critical CVEs, prioritizes internet-facing servers, patches, then rescans to confirm closure.

confusion_pairs.title: Code review vs Configuration review

a.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with code review.

b.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with configuration review.

bullets: Code review targets application logic; configuration review targets system/app settings and hardening.
If it mentions ‘functions, input validation, source code’ → code review. If it mentions ‘settings, policies, hardening’ → config review.
Code review finds missing output encoding (XSS risk). Config review finds TLS 1.0 enabled on the web server.

confusion_pairs.title: Qualitative risk analysis vs Quantitative risk analysis

a.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with qualitative risk analysis.

b.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with quantitative risk analysis.

bullets: Qualitative uses labels (High/Med/Low); quantitative uses numbers (money, probability) like ALE/SLE/ARO.
If it’s ‘rank/prioritize quickly’ → qualitative. If it’s ‘dollar impact/expected loss’ → quantitative.
Qualitative: ransomware risk = High. Quantitative: ALE = SLE × ARO = $50k × 0.4 = $20k/year.

confusion_pairs.title: Bug bounty vs Penetration test

a.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with bug bounty.

b.definition: Use when the scenario aligns with penetration test.

bullets: Bug bounty is open/continuous external discovery (varies by researcher); pentest is scoped, time-boxed, and deliverable-driven.
If it’s ‘public program, rewards, many researchers’ → bug bounty. If it’s ‘contracted, scoped engagement’ → pentest.
Bug bounty researcher reports IDOR for reward. Pentest team maps full attack chain and produces a formal report.
